DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Klein

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 77-year-old female who presents with bronchial stenosis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE

31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode 

31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 

ATTENDING Dr. Gomez

ASSISTANT Dr. Roberts

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Patient was already intubated for her exploratory laparotomy with Dr. Klein.
Initial Airway Inspection: The endotracheal tube is in good position. The visualized portion of the trachea is of normal caliber.
The carina is sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level.
Airway Exam Findings:


Bronchus Intermedius (BI): Small polypoid lesion noted, unchanged from prior.
Right Middle Lobe (RML): Moderately stenotic from extrinsic compression.


Secretions: Moderate clear thick secretions bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at Lateral Segment of RML (RB4) and Medial Segment of RML (RB5).
Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
Patient was left intubated for the rest of her surgery.
SPECIMENS

INTERVENTIONAL PULMONOLOGY OPERATIVE REPORT

DATE OF PROCEDURE: [Date] CC Referred Physician: Dr. Smith

INDICATION FOR OPERATION [REDACTED] is a 34-year-old male who presents with bronchial stenosis.
The nature, purpose, risks, benefits and alternatives to Bronchoscopy were discussed with the patient in detail.
CONSENT Obtained before the procedure.

PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS

J98.09 Other diseases of bronchus, not elsewhere classified 

PROCEDURE

31645 Therapeutic aspiration initial episode 

31624 Dx bronchoscope/lavage (BAL) 

ATTENDING Dr. Anderson

ASSISTANT Dr. Chen

ANESTHESIA General Anesthesia 

MONITORING Pulse oximetry, heart rate, telemetry, and BP were continuously monitored by an independent trained observer that was present throughout the entire procedure.
INSTRUMENTATION Disposable Bronchoscope 

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS None 

COMPLICATIONS None 

PROCEDURE IN DETAIL After the successful induction of anesthesia, a timeout was performed (confirming the patient's name, procedure type, and procedure location).
Patient Position: Patient was already intubated for his bowel resection with Dr. Smith.
Initial Airway Inspection: The endotracheal tube is in good position. The visualized portion of the trachea is of normal caliber.
The carina is sharp. The tracheobronchial tree was examined to at least the first subsegmental level.
Airway Exam Findings:


Bronchus Intermedius (BI): Mild mucosal erythema noted.
Lingula: Compressed by adjacent lymphadenopathy.


Secretions: Bloody tinged secretions bilaterally.
Therapeutic Aspiration Successful therapeutic aspiration was performed to clean out the Trachea (Distal 1/3), Right Mainstem, Bronchus Intermedius, and Left Mainstem from mucus.
Bronchoalveolar Lavage (BAL) Bronchial alveolar lavage was performed at Superior Lingular Segment (RB4).
Instilled 100 cc of NS, suction returned with 40 cc of NS.
Samples sent for Cell Count, Microbiology (Cultures/Viral/Fungal), and Cytology.

The patient tolerated the procedure well. There were no immediate complications.
Patient was left intubated for the rest of his surgery.
SPECIMENS

Lingula BAL

Follow-up BAL studies.
Consult ID for pulmonary fungal infection while admitted.

Repeat bronchoscopy in 2-3 months.
